Chapter on Distinguishing the Five Categories, Chapter 1, there are five dharmas:
1. form;
2. mind;
3. mental factors;
4. factors not directly associated with the mind;
5. unconditioned [dharmas].
What is form?
It refers to all forms, the four great elements and the forms derived from the four great elements.
The four great elements are the earth element, water element, fire element, and wind element.

translated: The forms derived from them are the eye faculty, ear faculty, nose faculty, tongue faculty, body faculty, visible forms, sounds, smells, tastes, part of the tangible, and unmanifest form.
What is mind?
It refers to mind, thought, and consciousness.
What is this again?
Namely, the six groups of consciousness, namely eye-consciousness, ear-consciousness, nose-consciousness, tongue-consciousness, body-consciousness, and mind-consciousness.
What are mental factors?
It means those dharmas that are associated with the mind.
What are they?

Namely, feeling, perception, volition, contact, attention, desire, resolve, mindfulness, concentration, wisdom, faith, effort, investigation, analysis, heedlessness, heedfulness, wholesome roots, unwholesome roots, indeterminate roots, all the fetters, bonds, latent afflictions, secondary afflictions, entanglements, all knowledge, all views, and all realizations.
There are also other such dharmas that are associated with the mind, collectively called mental factors.
What are the formations not associated with the mind?
It means those dharmas that are not associated with the mind.
What are they?

Namely, acquisition, non-perception concentration, cessation concentration, non-perception, life faculty, homogeneity, acquisition of support, acquisition of object, acquisition of place, birth, old age, duration, impermanence, name-group, sentence-group, syllable-group, and other such dharmas that are not associated with mind are collectively called mental factors not directly associated with mind.
What is unconditioned?
It refers to the three unconditioned [dharmas]:
First, space;
Second, non-analytical cessation;
Third, analytical cessation.
What is the earth element?
It refers to the quality of solidity.
What is the water element?
It refers to the quality of wetness.
What is the fire element?
It refers to the quality of heat.
What is the wind element?
It refers to the quality of lightness and movement.
What is the eye faculty?
It refers to the pure form that is the basis for eye consciousness.
What is the ear faculty?
It refers to the pure form that is the basis for ear consciousness.
What is the nose faculty?
It refers to the pure form that is the basis for nose consciousness.
What is the tongue faculty?
It is the pure form that is the basis of the tongue consciousness.
What is the body faculty?
It is the pure form that is the basis of the body consciousness.
What is form?
It is all forms, whether good forms, bad forms, or the two in between, which are like forms in space.
These forms are cognized by two consciousnesses, namely the eye consciousness and the mind consciousness.
Among them, one type is first cognized by the eye consciousness, and after the eye consciousness receives them, the mind consciousness subsequently cognizes them.
What is sound?
It is of two kinds, namely sound that has the great elements that are appropriated as its cause, and sound that has the great elements that are not appropriated as its cause.
These sounds are cognized by two consciousnesses, namely the ear consciousness and the mind consciousness.
Among them, one type is first cognized by the ear consciousness, and after the ear consciousness receives them, the mind consciousness subsequently cognizes them.
What is smell?
It is all smells, whether good smells, bad smells, or neutral smells, that are smelled by the nose.
These various smells are cognized by two consciousnesses, namely the nose consciousness and the mind consciousness.
Among them, one type of nose consciousness cognizes first, and after the nose consciousness has received [the smell], the mind consciousness subsequently cognizes.
What is taste?
It refers to all tastes, whether agreeable, disagreeable, or leading to equanimity, that are experienced by the tongue.
These various tastes are cognized by two consciousnesses, namely the tongue consciousness and the mind consciousness.
Among them, one type of tongue consciousness cognizes first, and after the tongue consciousness has received [the taste], the mind consciousness subsequently cognizes.
What is one part of the tangible?
It refers to smoothness, roughness, lightness, heaviness, cold, hunger, and thirst, which are contacted by the body.
These various tangibles and the four great elements are cognized by two consciousnesses, namely the body consciousness and the mind consciousness.
Among them, one type of body consciousness cognizes first, and after the body consciousness has received [the tangible], the mind consciousness subsequently cognizes.
What is non-indicative form?
It refers to form included in the factor [realm].
These and the five sense faculties are cognized by a single consciousness at all times, namely, the mental consciousness.
What is eye consciousness?
It is that which, based on the eye faculty, individually cognizes forms.
What is ear consciousness?
It is that which, based on the ear faculty, individually cognizes sounds.
What is nose consciousness?
It is that which, based on the nose faculty, individually cognizes smells.
What is tongue consciousness?
It is that which, based on the tongue faculty, individually cognizes tastes.
What is body consciousness?
It is that which, based on the body faculty, individually cognizes tactile objects.
What is mental consciousness?
It is that which, based on the mental faculty, cognizes all dharmas.
What is feeling?
It is the nature of experiencing.
There are three kinds of this, namely, pleasant feeling, painful feeling, and neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling.
What is conceptualization?
It is the nature of grasping images.
There are three kinds of this, namely, small conceptualization, large conceptualization, and immeasurable conceptualization.
What is volition?
It is the nature of mental activity, which is mental action.
There are three kinds, namely wholesome volition, unwholesome volition, and indeterminate volition.
What is contact?
It is the nature of the union of the three.
There are three kinds, namely contact that is conducive to pleasant feeling, contact that is conducive to painful feeling, and contact that is conducive to neither painful nor pleasant feeling.
What is attention?
It is the nature of the mind's arousal.
There are three kinds, namely attention of the learner, attention of the post-learner, and attention that is neither of the learner nor the post-learner.
What is desire?
It is the nature of delight in activity.
What is resolve?
It is the nature of the mind's right resolve, having resolved, and will resolve.
What is mindfulness?
It is the nature of the mind's clear recollection.
What is concentration?
It is the nature of the mind's one-pointedness.
What is wisdom?
It is the nature of the mind's discernment of dharmas.
What is faith?
It is the nature of the mind's clarity and purity.
What is vigor?
It is the nature of the mind's courage and resoluteness.
What is applied thought?
It is the nature of the mind's gross agitation.
What is investigation?
It refers to the subtle movement of the mind.
What is negligence?
It refers to the nature of not cultivating wholesome dharmas.
What is vigilance?
It refers to the nature of cultivating wholesome dharmas.
What are the wholesome roots?
There are three wholesome roots, namely the wholesome roots of non-greed, non-hatred, and non-delusion.
What are the unwholesome roots?
There are three unwholesome roots, namely the unwholesome roots of greed, hatred, and delusion.
What are the indeterminate roots?
There are four indeterminate roots, namely indeterminate craving, indeterminate views, indeterminate pride, and indeterminate ignorance.

There are nine kinds of fetters, namely the fetter of craving, the fetter of anger, the fetter of pride, the fetter of ignorance, the fetter of views, the fetter of grasping, the fetter of doubt, the fetter of jealousy, and the fetter of stinginess.
What is the fetter of craving?
It refers to the craving of the three realms.
What is the fetter of anger?
It refers to the ability to harm sentient beings.
What is the fetter of pride?

Namely, the seven types of pride, which are pride, over-pride, excessive pride, self-pride, superior pride, lesser pride, and false pride.ğŸ”½Pride means considering oneself superior to inferiors, or equal to equals, and due to this, one is presently proud, has been proud, and will be proud, with a mind of arrogance and contempt.
Over-pride means considering oneself superior to equals, or equal to those superior, and due to this, one is presently proud, has been proud, and will be proud, with a mind of arrogance and contempt.
Excessive pride means considering oneself superior to those superior, and due to this, one is presently proud, has been proud, and will be proud, with a mind of arrogance and contempt.

Self-pride means observing the five appropriated aggregates as either the self or what belongs to the self, and due to this, one is presently proud, has been proud, and will be proud, with a mind of arrogance and contempt.

Arrogance means, in regard to a superior and unsurpassed realization of the Dharma that one has not yet attained, to think I have attained it; in regard to a superior and unsurpassed realization of the Dharma that one has not yet reached, to think I have reached it; in regard to a superior and unsurpassed realization of the Dharma that one has not yet touched, to think I have touched it; in regard to a superior and unsurpassed realization of the Dharma that one has not yet realized, to think I have realized it. Because of this, one is already arrogant, will be arrogant, and is arrogant, with a mind of self-elevation and contempt for others.

Humility means, in regard to others who are superior in many ways, to think oneself slightly inferior. Because of this, one is already arrogant, will be arrogant, and is arrogant, with a mind of self-elevation and contempt for others.

False arrogance means, in reality lacking virtue, to think oneself virtuous. Because of this, one is already arrogant, will be arrogant, and is arrogant, with a mind of self-elevation and contempt for others.
What is the fetter of ignorance?
It means lack of knowledge in the three realms.
What is the fetter of views?
It means the three views, namely the view of self-existence, the view of grasping extremes, and wrong views.
The view of self-existence refers to the view that the five aggregates of clinging are the self or belong to the self, and the acquiescence, delight, wisdom, and insight that arise from this view.
The view of extremes refers to the view that the five aggregates of clinging are either annihilated or eternal, and the acquiescence, delight, wisdom, and insight that arise from this view.
Wrong views refer to the denial of causes and effects, the denial of function, and the denial of real events, and the acquiescence, delight, wisdom, and insight that arise from this view.
What are the fetters of grasping?
They are the two kinds of grasping, namely the grasping of views and the grasping of precepts and observances.
The grasping of views refers to the view that the five aggregates of clinging are supreme, excellent, high, or ultimate, and the acquiescence, delight, wisdom, and insight that arise from this view.

The grasping of precepts and observances refers to the view that the five aggregates of clinging can bring purification, liberation, or escape, and the acquiescence, delight, wisdom, and insight that arise from this view.
What is the fetter of doubt?
It refers to doubt regarding the truths.
What is the fetter of jealousy?
It refers to the mind being envious.
What is the fetter of stinginess?
It is the miserliness of the mind.
What are the bonds?
The fetters are also called bonds.
There are also three bonds, namely the bonds of greed, hatred, and delusion.

translated: There are seven kinds of latent tendencies, namely the latent tendencies of desire, hatred, greed for existence, pride, ignorance, views, and doubt.
The latent tendency of desire for desire realm objects is of five kinds, namely the greed that is eliminated by seeing suffering, origination, cessation, the path, and by cultivation.
The latent tendency of hatred is of five kinds, namely the hatred that is eliminated by seeing suffering, origination, cessation, the path, and by cultivation.
The latent tendency of greed for existence is of ten kinds, namely the five associated with the form realm and the five associated with the formless realm.
The five associated with the form realm are the greed that is eliminated by seeing suffering, origination, cessation, the path, and by cultivation in the form realm.
The five associated with the formless realm are also like this.
There are fifteen kinds of latent afflictions of pride, namely, five belonging to the desire realm, five belonging to the form realm, and five belonging to the formless realm.
The five belonging to the desire realm are the pride eliminated by the paths of seeing suffering, origination, cessation, and the path, and by cultivation, belonging to the desire realm.
The five belonging to the form and formless realms are also like this.
There are fifteen kinds of latent afflictions of ignorance, namely, five belonging to the desire realm, five belonging to the form realm, and five belonging to the formless realm.
The five belonging to the desire realm are the ignorance eliminated by the paths of seeing suffering, origination, cessation, and the path, and by cultivation, belonging to the desire realm.

The five belonging to the form and formless realms are also like this.ğŸ”½There are thirty-six kinds of latent afflictions of views, namely, twelve belonging to the desire realm, twelve belonging to the form realm, and twelve belonging to the formless realm.ğŸ”½The twelve belonging to the desire realm are the afflicted view of self, extreme view, wrong view, view of holding a view as paramount, and view of holding morality and asceticism as paramount, eliminated by the paths of seeing suffering and the path, belonging to the desire realm.
The view of holding a view as paramount and view of holding morality and asceticism as paramount eliminated by the paths of seeing origination and cessation, belonging to the desire realm.
The same applies to the twelve each in the form and formless realms.
There are twelve kinds of latent afflictions of doubt, namely, four in the desire realm, four in the form realm, and four in the formless realm.
The four in the desire realm are the latent afflictions of doubt eliminated by seeing the truths of suffering, origination, cessation, and path in the desire realm.
The same applies to the four each in the form and formless realms.
What are the secondary afflictions?
The latent afflictions are also called secondary afflictions.
There are secondary afflictions that are not called latent afflictions, namely, all the defiled mental activities in the aggregate of volitional activities except for the latent afflictions.
There are eight kinds of entanglements, namely, torpor, restlessness, sleep, regret, envy, stinginess, lack of conscience, and lack of sense of shame.

There are ten kinds of knowledge, namely, knowledge of dharmas, inferential knowledge, knowledge of others' minds, conventional knowledge, knowledge of suffering, knowledge of origination, knowledge of cessation, knowledge of the path, knowledge of elimination, and knowledge of non-production.
What is knowledge of dharmas?

That is, the pure cognition that takes as its object the conditioned factors of the desire realm, the causes of the conditioned factors of the desire realm, the cessation of the conditioned factors of the desire realm, and the path that is able to eliminate the conditioned factors of the desire realm.
There is also pure cognition that takes the cognition of dharmas and the stage of the cognition of dharmas as its object, which is also called the cognition of dharmas.
What is the cognition of other beings' minds?

That is, if cognition is accomplished through cultivation, is the fruit of cultivation, and is the cognition that is attained through cultivation and not lost, the minds and mental factors of other beings in the desire and form realms that are combined and manifest, and a part of the pure minds and mental factors of other beings, are all called the cognition of other beings' minds.
What is conventional cognition?
That is, all contaminated wisdom.
What is the cognition of suffering?
That is, the pure cognition that arises from contemplating the impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and non-self of the five appropriated aggregates.
What is the cognition of the arising of suffering?
That is, the undefiled knowledge that arises from contemplating the causes of the contaminated [dharmas] as causes, accumulation, production, and conditions.
What is the knowledge of cessation?
That is, the undefiled knowledge that arises from contemplating cessation, tranquility, excellence, and separation as cessation.
What is the knowledge of the path?
That is, the undefiled knowledge that arises from contemplating the path, suchness, practice, and exit as the path.
What is the knowledge of extinction?

That is, the knowledge, vision, illumination, understanding, wisdom, insight, and contemplation that arises from the thorough knowledge of oneself, thinking, I have already known suffering, I have already abandoned accumulation, I have already realized cessation, I have already cultivated the path, are all called the knowledge of extinction.
What is the knowledge of non-arising?

That is, the knowledge, vision, illumination, understanding, wisdom, insight, and contemplation that arises from the thorough knowledge of oneself, thinking, I have already known suffering and do not need to know it again, I have already abandoned accumulation and do not need to abandon it again, I have already realized cessation and do not need to realize it again, I have already cultivated the path and do not need to cultivate it again, are all called the knowledge of non-arising.
As for all views, some knowledges are also called views.
There are views that are not knowledges, namely the eight forbearances at the end of the path of insight.
The first is the forbearance of the knowledge of the dharma of suffering;
the second is the forbearance of the knowledge of the similarity of suffering;
the third is the forbearance of the knowledge of the dharma of accumulation;
the fourth is the forbearance of the knowledge of the similarity of accumulation;
the fifth is the forbearance of the knowledge of the dharma of cessation;
the sixth is the forbearance of the knowledge of the similarity of cessation;
the seventh is the forbearance of the knowledge of the dharma of the path;
the eighth is the forbearance of the knowledge of the similarity of the path.
As for all realizations, both knowledge and views are called realizations.
What is attainment?
It refers to the attainment of dharmas.
What is the attainment of non-perception?
It refers to the cessation of mind and mental factors preceded by the intention to escape from the perception of defilements that have already been abandoned, but not yet abandoned above.
What is the attainment of cessation?
It refers to the cessation of mind and mental factors preceded by the intention to rest in the perception of defilements that have already been abandoned in the sphere of nothingness.
What is the state of non-perception?
It refers to the cessation of mind and mental factors in the rebirth in the heaven of non-perception.
What is the life faculty?
It refers to the life span of the three realms.
What is the homogeneity of sentient beings?
It refers to the nature of sentient beings belonging to the same class.
What is the attainment of the basis?
It refers to the attainment of the basis.
What is the attainment of the factors of existence?
It refers to the attainment of the aggregates.
What is the attainment of the sense bases?
It refers to the attainment of the internal and external sense bases.
What is birth?
It refers to causing the aggregates to arise.
What is aging?
It refers to causing the aggregates to mature.
What is duration?
It refers to causing the conditioned factors that have already arisen not to be destroyed.
What is impermanence?
It refers to causing the conditioned factors that have already arisen to perish and be destroyed.
What is a collection of names?
It refers to the collection of words.
What is a collection of phrases?
It refers to the completion of syllables.
What is a collection of letters?
It refers to the multitude of letters.
What is space?
It refers to the emptiness, vastness, and unobstructedness of the essence, which does not obstruct form and action.
What is non-analytical cessation?
It refers to cessation that is not due to the separation from the defilements.
What is analytical cessation?
It refers to cessation that is due to the separation from the defilements.
2. The Chapter on Distinguishing the Various Cognitions, Part 1 of 2 in the Abhidharma-nyÄyÄnusÄra ÅšÄstra. There are ten cognitions, as explained before.
What is the object of dharma cognition?
It is the conditioned dharmas of the desire realm and a part of the unconditioned dharmas.
What is the object of inferential cognition?
It is the conditioned dharmas of the form and formless realms and a part of the unconditioned dharmas.
What is the object of cognition of others' minds?
It is the combined present minds and mental factors of others in the desire and form realms and a part of the unconditioned minds and mental factors.
What is the object of conventional cognition?
It is all dharmas.
What is the object of cognition of suffering?
It is the five appropriated aggregates.
What is the object of cognition of the arising of suffering?
It is the causes of contaminated dharmas.
What is the object of cognition of the cessation of suffering?
It is cessation obtained through discerning insight.
What is the object of cognition of the path?
It is the training and beyond-training dharmas.
What is the object of cognition of exhaustion?
It is all conditioned dharmas and cessation obtained through discerning insight.
What is the object of the cognition of non-arising?
It takes all conditioned dharmas and cessation through discernment as its object.
Why does the cognition of dharmas take the conditioned dharmas of the desire realm and part of the undefiled dharmas as its object?
Answer:

Because the cognition of dharmas knows the conditioned dharmas of the desire realm, the causes of the conditioned dharmas, the cessation of the conditioned dharmas, and the path that can eliminate the conditioned dharmas.
Why does the cognition of categories take the conditioned dharmas of the form and formless realms and part of the undefiled dharmas as its object?
Answer:

Because the cognition of categories knows the conditioned dharmas of the form and formless realms, the causes of the conditioned dharmas, the cessation of the conditioned dharmas, and the path that can eliminate the conditioned dharmas.

Why does the cognition of others' minds take the combined and presently manifest minds and mental factors of others in the desire and form realms, and part of the undefiled minds and mental factors of others as its object?
Answer:

Because the cognition of others' minds knows the combined and presently manifest minds and mental factors of others in the desire and form realms, and part of the undefiled minds and mental factors of others.
Why does conventional cognition take all dharmas as its object?
Answer:
Conventional knowledge knows all dharmas, whether they are induced by reasoning, not induced by reasoning, or neither induced by reasoning nor not induced by reasoning.
Why does the knowledge of suffering take the five appropriated aggregates as its object?
Answer:
Because the knowledge of suffering knows that the five appropriated aggregates are impermanent, suffering, empty, and non-self.
Why does the knowledge of the accumulation take contaminated causes as its object?
Answer:
Because the knowledge of the accumulation knows that contaminated causes are causes, accumulations, births, and conditions.
Why does the knowledge of cessation take cessation through discernment as its object?
Answer:
Because the knowledge of cessation knows that cessation through discernment is cessation, tranquility, excellence, and separation.
Why does the knowledge of the path take the dharmas of learners and post-learners as its object?
Answer:
Because the knowledge of the path knows that the dharmas of learners and post-learners are the path, suchness, practice, and exit.
Why does the knowledge of extinction take all conditioned dharmas and cessation through discernment as its object?
Answer:

Because the knowledge of extinction itself universally knows, I have already known suffering, I have already eliminated accumulation, I have already realized cessation, I have already cultivated the path.
Why does the knowledge of non-arising take all conditioned dharmas and cessation through discernment as its object?
Answer:

Because the knowledge of non-arising itself fully knows: I have already known suffering and will not know it again. I have already eliminated accumulation and will not eliminate it again. I have already realized cessation and will not realize it again. I have already cultivated the path and will not cultivate it again.
Is the knowledge of dharmas all of the knowledges or a part of some knowledges?
Answer:

The knowledge of dharmas is all of the knowledge of dharmas and a part of seven knowledges, namely the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of accumulation, the knowledge of cessation, the knowledge of the path, the knowledge of extinction, and the knowledge of non-arising.
Is the knowledge of variety all of the knowledges or a part of some knowledges?
Answer:

The knowledge of variety is all of the knowledge of variety and a part of seven knowledges, namely the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of accumulation, the knowledge of cessation, the knowledge of the path, the knowledge of extinction, and the knowledge of non-arising.
Is the knowledge of others' minds all of the knowledges or a part of some knowledges?
Answer:

The knowledge of others' minds is the whole of the knowledge of others' minds and a part of four knowledges, namely the knowledge of dharmas, inferential knowledge, conventional knowledge, and the knowledge of the path.
How many knowledges are conventional knowledge in its entirety and how many are a part of conventional knowledge?
Answer:
Conventional knowledge is the whole of conventional knowledge and a part of one knowledge, namely the knowledge of others' minds.
How many knowledges are the knowledge of suffering in its entirety and how many are a part of the knowledge of suffering?
Answer:

The knowledge of suffering is the whole of the knowledge of suffering and a part of four knowledges, namely the knowledge of dharmas, inferential knowledge, the knowledge of elimination, and the knowledge of non-production.
The knowledge of accumulation and the knowledge of cessation should be understood in the same way.
How many knowledges are the knowledge of the path in its entirety and how many are a part of the knowledge of the path?
Answer:

The knowledge of the path is the whole of the knowledge of the path and a part of five knowledges, namely the knowledge of dharmas, inferential knowledge, the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of elimination, and the knowledge of non-production.
How many knowledges are the knowledge of elimination in its entirety and how many are a part of the knowledge of elimination?
Answer:

The knowledge of elimination is the whole of the knowledge of elimination and six kinds of knowledge in part, namely, the knowledge of dharmas, the knowledge of the principle of path, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of the cause, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path.
The knowledge of non-production is also like this.
Why is the knowledge of dharmas the whole of the knowledge of dharmas?
Answer:
Because the knowledge of dharmas knows the formations of the desire realm, the cause of the formations, the cessation of the formations, and the path that can eliminate the formations.
Why is the knowledge of dharmas a part of the knowledge of others' minds?
Answer:
Because the knowledge of dharmas knows the pure mind and mental factors of others in the path that can eliminate the formations of the desire realm.
Why is the knowledge of dharmas a part of the knowledge of suffering?
Answer:
Because the knowledge of dharmas knows that the five appropriated aggregates of the desire realm are impermanent, suffering, empty, and non-self.
Why is the knowledge of dharmas a part of the knowledge of the cause?
Answer:
Because the knowledge of dharmas knows the cause, accumulation, birth, and condition of the formations of the desire realm.
Why is the knowledge of dharmas a part of the knowledge of cessation?
Answer:
Dharma cognition knows the cessation of all conditioned things connected to the desire realm as cessation, calm, wonderful, and escape.
Why is dharma cognition a part of the cognition of the path?
Answer:
Dharma cognition knows the path that can eliminate all conditioned things connected to the desire realm as the path, suchness, practice, and exit.
Why is dharma cognition a part of the cognition of exhaustion?
Answer:

Dharma cognition universally knows for oneself: I have already known the suffering of all conditioned things connected to the desire realm, I have already eliminated the accumulation of all conditioned things connected to the desire realm, I have already realized the cessation of all conditioned things connected to the desire realm, I have already cultivated the path that can eliminate all conditioned things connected to the desire realm.
Why is dharma cognition a part of the cognition of non-arising?
Answer:

Dharma cognition universally knows for oneself: I have already known the suffering of all conditioned things connected to the desire realm and will not know it again, I have already eliminated the accumulation of all conditioned things connected to the desire realm and will not eliminate it again, I have already realized the cessation of all conditioned things connected to the desire realm and will not realize it again, I have already cultivated the path that can eliminate all conditioned things connected to the desire realm and will not cultivate it again.
Why is the class of cognition the whole of the class of cognition?
Answer:

Because the class of cognition knows the various practices, the causes of various practices, the cessation of various practices, and the path that can eliminate various practices in the form and formless realms.
Why is the class of cognition a part of the cognition of others' minds?
Answer:
Because the class of cognition knows the impure minds and mental factors of others in the path that can eliminate various practices in the form and formless realms.
Why is the class of cognition a part of the cognition of suffering?
Answer:
Because the class of cognition knows that the five appropriated aggregates in the form and formless realms are impermanent, suffering, empty, and non-self.
Why is the class of cognition a part of the cognition of the origin?
Answer:
Because the class of cognition knows the causes, the origin, the production, and the condition of the causes of various practices in the form and formless realms.
Why is the class of cognition a part of the cognition of cessation?
Answer:
Because the class of cognition knows the cessation, tranquility, subtlety, and separation of various practices in the form and formless realms.
Why is the class of cognition a part of the cognition of the path?

Because inferential knowledge knows the path that can eliminate the conditioned factors associated with the form and formless realms, as well as the truth of the path, the practice, and the exit.
Why is inferential knowledge a part of the knowledge of elimination?
Answer:

Because inferential knowledge universally knows for oneself: I have already known the suffering of the conditioned factors associated with the form and formless realms, I have already eliminated the accumulation of the conditioned factors associated with the form and formless realms, I have already realized the cessation of the conditioned factors associated with the form and formless realms, I have already cultivated the path that can eliminate the conditioned factors associated with the form and formless realms.
Why is inferential knowledge a part of the knowledge of non-arising?
Answer:

Because inferential knowledge universally knows for oneself: I have already known the suffering of the conditioned factors associated with the form and formless realms and do not need to know it again, I have already eliminated the accumulation of the conditioned factors associated with the form and formless realms and do not need to eliminate it again, I have already realized the cessation of the conditioned factors associated with the form and formless realms and do not need to realize it again, I have already cultivated the path that can eliminate the conditioned factors associated with the form and formless realms and do not need to cultivate it again.
Why is the knowledge of others' minds the entirety of the knowledge of others' minds?
Answer:
Because the knowledge of others' minds knows the combined and present minds and mental factors of the desire and form realms, and a part of the pure minds and mental factors of others.
Why is the knowledge of others' minds a part of the knowledge of dharmas?
Answer:
Because the knowledge of others' minds knows the pure minds and mental factors of others in the path that can eliminate the conditioned factors of the desire realm.
Why is the knowledge of others' minds a part of the knowledge of variety?
Answer:
Because the knowledge of others' minds knows the pure minds and mental factors of others in the path that can eliminate the conditioned factors of the form and formless realms.
Why is the knowledge of others' minds a part of the knowledge of convention?
Answer:
Because the knowledge of others' minds knows the defiled minds and mental factors of others.
Why is the knowledge of others' minds a part of the knowledge of the path?
Answer:
Because the knowledge of others' minds knows the pure minds and mental factors of others in the noble path.
Why is the knowledge of convention the entirety of the knowledge of convention?
Answer:

Because conventional knowledge knows all dharmas, whether they are induced by correct reasoning, not induced by correct reasoning, or neither induced by correct reasoning nor not induced by correct reasoning.
Why is conventional knowledge a part of knowledge of others' minds?
Answer:
Because conventional knowledge knows the defiled minds and mental factors of others.
Why is knowledge of suffering the entirety of knowledge of suffering?
Answer:
Because knowledge of suffering knows the five appropriated aggregates as impermanent, suffering, empty, and non-self.
Why is knowledge of suffering a part of knowledge of dharmas?
Answer:
Because knowledge of suffering knows the five appropriated aggregates of the desire realm as impermanent, suffering, empty, and non-self.
Why is knowledge of suffering a part of inferential knowledge?
Answer:
Because knowledge of suffering knows the five appropriated aggregates of the form and formless realms as impermanent, suffering, empty, and non-self.
Why is knowledge of suffering a part of knowledge of elimination?
Answer:
Because knowledge of suffering itself fully knows that I have already known suffering.
Why is the knowledge of suffering a part of the knowledge of non-arising?
Answer:
Because the knowledge of suffering itself thoroughly knows that I have already known suffering and will not know it again.
Why is the knowledge of the accumulation the whole of the knowledge of the accumulation?
Answer:
Because the knowledge of the accumulation knows the causes, accumulation, birth, and conditions of contaminated causes.
Why is the knowledge of the accumulation a part of the knowledge of dharmas?
Answer:
Because the knowledge of the accumulation knows the causes, accumulation, birth, and conditions of the formations associated with the desire realm.
Why is the knowledge of the accumulation a part of the knowledge of species?
Answer: Because the knowledge of the accumulation knows the causes, accumulation, birth, and conditions of the formations associated with the form and formless realms.
Why is the knowledge of the accumulation a part of the knowledge of exhaustion?
Answer:
Because the knowledge of the accumulation itself thoroughly knows that I have already eliminated the accumulation.
Why is the knowledge of the accumulation a part of the knowledge of non-arising?
Answer:
Because the knowledge of the accumulation itself thoroughly knows that I have already eliminated the accumulation and will not eliminate it again.
Why is the knowledge of cessation the whole of the knowledge of cessation?
Answer:
Extinction knowledge knows the extinction of cessation, tranquility, subtlety, and separation.
Why is extinction knowledge a part of dharma knowledge?
Answer:
Extinction knowledge knows the extinction of the cessation of the various conditioned phenomena of the desire realm, tranquility, subtlety, and separation.
Why is extinction knowledge a part of subsequent knowledge?
Answer:
Extinction knowledge knows the extinction of the cessation of the various conditioned phenomena of the form and formless realms, tranquility, subtlety, and separation.
Why is extinction knowledge a part of knowledge of elimination?
Answer:
Extinction knowledge universally knows for oneself that one has already realized extinction.
Why is extinction knowledge a part of knowledge of non-arising?
Answer:
Extinction knowledge universally knows for oneself that one has already realized extinction and will not realize it again.
